question: [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/validator_txns/dkg.rs] [Function: process_dkg_result_inner()] [Epoch manipulation] Can a malicious validator submit a DKG transcript with a future epoch number that gets accepted before the epoch actually transitions, allowing them to pre-commit validator set changes and manipulate the next epoch's validator composition? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/validator_txns/dkg.rs] [Function: process_dkg_result_inner()] [Epoch replay] Does the epoch check at line 96 prevent replay attacks where an attacker resubmits a valid DKG transcript from a previous epoch to force a rollback or create conflicting validator sets across nodes? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/validator_txns/dkg.rs] [Function: process_dkg_result_inner()] [Race condition] Can concurrent epoch transitions create a TOCTOU (Time-of-Check-Time-of-Use) vulnerability where the epoch number is validated at line 96 but changes before VM execution at line 120, allowing stale DKG results to be committed? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/validator_txns/dkg.rs] [Function: process_dkg_result_inner()] [Integer overflow] If dkg_node.metadata.epoch or config_resource.epoch() overflow or wrap around at maximum u64 values, can an attacker craft epoch numbers that bypass the equality check at line 96 and submit fraudulent transcripts? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/validator_txns/dkg.rs] [Function: process_dkg_result_inner()] [Configuration manipulation] Can an attacker exploit the ConfigurationResource fetch at line 89-90 by corrupting the on-chain configuration to make config_resource.epoch() return a manipulated value that always matches malicious transcript epochs? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/validator_txns/dkg.rs] [Function: process_dkg_result_inner()] [Deserialization DoS] Can an attacker submit extremely large transcript_bytes (e.g., GB-sized) that consume excessive memory during bcs::from_bytes deserialization at line 102-104, causing validator nodes to crash or OOM before the expected failure is caught? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/validator_txns/dkg.rs] [Function: process_dkg_result_inner()] [Type confusion] Can malicious transcript_bytes be crafted with valid BCS structure but incorrect type layout that deserializes successfully at line 102-104 but causes undefined behavior or memory corruption during subsequent verification at line 107-108? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/validator_txns/dkg.rs] [Function: process_dkg_result_inner()] [Malformed BCS bypass] Does the bcs::from_bytes call at line 102-104 properly validate all BCS invariants, or can specially crafted bytes bypass deserialization errors while creating invalid Transcript objects that later crash the verification logic? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/validator_txns/dkg.rs] [Function: process_dkg_result_inner()] [Recursion attack] Can deeply nested BCS structures in transcript_bytes cause stack overflow during deserialization at line 102-104, bypassing the expected TranscriptDeserializationFailed error and causing validator crashes? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/validator_txns/dkg.rs] [Function: process_dkg_result_inner()] [Panic vulnerability] If bcs::from_bytes panics instead of returning an Err during malformed input processing at line 102-104, can this bypass the map_err handler and crash the validator thread, causing consensus disruption? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/validator_txns/dkg.rs] [Function: process_dkg_result_inner()] [Weak parameters] Can an attacker exploit weaknesses in pub_params generation at line 101 by manipulating in_progress_session_state.metadata to create DKG parameters that make verify_transcript always succeed regardless of transcript validity? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/validator_txns/dkg.rs] [Function: process_dkg_result_inner()] [Verification bypass] Does DefaultDKG::verify_transcript at line 107-108 perform constant-time operations, or can timing side-channels leak information allowing attackers to forge transcripts through repeated submission and timing analysis? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/validator_txns/dkg.rs] [Function: process_dkg_result_inner()] [Cryptographic downgrade] Can an attacker manipulate in_progress_session_state.metadata to downgrade cryptographic parameters (e.g., smaller group orders, weaker curves) used in new_public_params at line 101, weakening the DKG verification? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/validator_txns/dkg.rs] [Function: process_dkg_result_inner()] [Signature malleability] If the transcript contains malleable signatures or proofs, can an attacker create multiple valid transcripts from a single legitimate one, causing consensus disagreement when different validators accept different malleable versions? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/validator_txns/dkg.rs] [Function: process_dkg_result_inner()] [Batch verification weakness] Does verify_transcript verify the entire transcript atomically, or can partial verification allow attackers to construct transcripts that pass verification but contain invalid components that corrupt state when published on-chain? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/validator_txns/dkg.rs] [Function: process_dkg_result_inner()] [Missing resource exploitation] When DKGState is missing at line 87-88 and MissingResourceDKGState is returned, can an attacker exploit the discarded transaction status at line 72 to repeatedly submit DKG transactions that burn gas/fees without penalty? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/validator_txns/dkg.rs] [Function: process_dkg_result_inner()] [State race condition] Can concurrent access to OnChainConfig::fetch_config at line 88 and line 89-90 create inconsistent state reads where DKGState and ConfigurationResource are from different epochs, causing verification against mismatched parameters? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/validator_txns/dkg.rs] [Function: process_dkg_result_inner()] [in_progress manipulation] Can an attacker exploit the unwrap of in_progress.ok_or at line 92-93 by corrupting the DKGState such that in_progress is Some() but contains malicious metadata, bypassing the MissingResourceInprogressDKGSession check? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/validator_txns/dkg.rs] [Function: process_dkg_result_inner()] [Resource exhaustion] Can repeated OnChainConfig::fetch_config calls at lines 88 and 89-90 be exploited to cause excessive state reads and database lookups, degrading validator performance during critical epoch transitions? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/validator_txns/dkg.rs] [Function: process_dkg_result_inner()] [Stale state attack] If the resolver provides cached state instead of latest committed state, can attackers submit DKG transcripts that verify against stale in_progress_session_state but are invalid for current epoch, causing state divergence? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/validator_txns/dkg.rs] [Function: process_dkg_result_inner()] [Infinite computation] Since UnmeteredGasMeter is used at line 111, can an attacker craft a DKG transcript that causes the FINISH_WITH_DKG_RESULT function to enter infinite loops or perform unbounded computation, freezing validator nodes? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/validator_txns/dkg.rs] [Function: process_dkg_result_inner()] [Memory exhaustion] With UnmeteredGasMeter at line 111 providing unlimited gas, can malicious transcript_bytes trigger excessive memory allocation in execute_function_bypass_visibility at lines 120-128, causing validator OOM crashes? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/validator_txns/dkg.rs] [Function: process_dkg_result_inner()] [Storage explosion] Can the unmetered execution at line 111 allow FINISH_WITH_DKG_RESULT to write unlimited state data to storage, filling validator disks and causing consensus failure when nodes run out of space? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/validator_txns/dkg.rs] [Function: process_dkg_result_inner()] [Stack overflow] Without gas limits from UnmeteredGasMeter at line 111, can deeply recursive Move code in FINISH_WITH_DKG_RESULT cause stack overflow and validator crashes during DKG result processing? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/validator_txns/dkg.rs] [Function: process_dkg_result_inner()] [Determinism violation] Can the absence of gas metering at line 111 cause non-deterministic execution where different validators timeout at different points, leading to state divergence and consensus failure? (Critical)
